instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7151: What is R7151? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7122: What is R7122? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7152: What is R7152? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
Macbook looks very clean no signs of liquid damage, Im defiantly the first person to open this, 

I presumed it was just a battery issue but tried it now with 3 known good batteries, 

With a battery connected I get no boot no screen just fan spin up for a few seconds then stops then spins then stops and so on it goes.. 

If I remove the battery and turn on in SMC bypass it boots and works fine and if I shut it down from here I can turn it on again via power button and it will work fine until I remove the magsafe, the ill need to start first time in smc bypass again, 

Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
Did you test with original 45/60W Magsafe 2 charger?
What is exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage, without battery connected?

Check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
Also check <SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_VSENSE</SIGNAL>/ISENSE.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
45/60W Magsafe 2 charger? = Yes :)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage = 8.57v

pins 17/18  = 33.6 ohm
pins 27/28 = .542k

<SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_VSENSE</SIGNAL>  = 2.73v
ISENSE _DCIN_ ISENSE  = 30,0 mA - Jumps around the mA range a bit as the machine powers up the off,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
Check <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22 and fix pins 27/28 problem.
You should get 2-3 ohm between 17/18, so check <RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR>/52 too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22 both seem fine at 16. 3v on both traces and upto <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
<RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR>/52 both seem fine getting 8.56v

It still boots with smc bypass but it just does the on off fan spin without,

I'm kinda stuck now don't know what to check, before having this help from you I would try reflowing Smc. Is this wise?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message: Take your time and maybe tell us exact ohm value of mentioned resistors...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
Take my time is such good advice!, 

Trying to juggle jobs in between the Mrs and a 4yr old running round the place wanting to put his toy cars under my scope!

Drink in hand and a lot more relaxed I find,,,

<RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> =  .245 k
<RESISTOR>R7122</RESISTOR> =  138.7 Ohm

<RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR> = 8.8 Ohm
R71572 = 0.00

 Change R71572 ? 

( P.s Thanks for the reminder that this game requires patience!, )

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
Check values mentioned on schematic and replace damaged resistors.
Only <RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> looks really good; why to change it???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
Today using a donor board I replaced the following and now have these readings

<RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> =  10.0 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R7122</RESISTOR> =  10.0 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR> =   2.2 Ohm 

My god how fkin small are these things!

Same problem still here, will boot in SMC Bypass but just fan spin fan stop etc when powering on. 

( Gutted TBH after all that resistor surgery I was convinced this would sort it )

Now getting
resistance between pins 17-18 =00.2 ohm    ( Could this be a dodgy <CAPACITOR>C7150</CAPACITOR>?)
                   between pins 27/28 =20.5 ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
You should have 2-3 ohms between pins 17/18.
Remove <CAPACITOR>C7150</CAPACITOR> and test again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
Removed <CAPACITOR>C7150</CAPACITOR> and get 16.6ohm

I think hmm this can't be right, so put back <CAPACITOR>C7150</CAPACITOR> and get 16.6!
Remove <CAPACITOR>C7150</CAPACITOR> again left off board still getting 16.6 ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
Check again <RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR>/52 and traces.
Try to get 2-3 ohm there.
It should work even with 16, but is better to get correct value...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
Gone over all of yesterday's work all resistors are good with perfect readings, all traces are good area nice and clean.

Now pins 17/18 reading 30 ohms!

I even tried replacing <RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR>/2, with others from a second donor board, it must be something else pulling this up?

Still get 3 seconds on 3 seconds off fan spin and only boots in smc bypass

Would it be worth try swapping <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> with one from a donor board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
2.2 + 0 + 0.01 cannot be equal 30 for sure!
So you still have a problem there.

Just in case, check <SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>BMON_ISENSE</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL>.
Do you get correct <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
Yer I'm checking the readings on the donor boards and as you say should be 2/3 ohm, I just can't find any bad trace or bad component in that area they all test fine and look the part all traces test fine to.

<SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 30mv
<SIGNAL>SMC_BMON_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 60mv

<SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_VSENSE</SIGNAL> = 2.75v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> = 2.44v

 <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> is a solid 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
Did you replace <RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR>/52 with correct values?

"<SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> = 2.44v"
Looks too high for me; 2.1V expected.
What is exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage (charger alone)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR>/52 replaced using a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a donor board. the schematics say that these parts are identical on both boards.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage = 8.57v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
""<SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> = 2.44v"
Looks too high for me; 2.1V expected."
What is actual reading?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
1.443v

Just checked my notepad and it was reading this same value also yesterday and I must have made a typo when posting readings, sorry,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
1.44V looks good.
I posted 2.1V for 12.6V as reference; correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.5V in this case, sorry.

Try changing <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, just in case.
Do you get correct resistance between pins 17/18 now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
So just removed <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> from my donor board, usual flux and heat it pops off as normal and I set aside to use as the replacement,

Then to this board apply flux and heat.. Wtf! It would not budge! Solder flowing chip still wouldn't move, I had to up the heat and the airflow and gently try to move the chip it felt welded to the board.

Then when it came off and I properly clean the area it seems part of the board layer was fused,

[ATTACH]60681[/ATTACH]

Pins 11, 12 and 13 are gone!

Looks like it's easy enough to use pad strips to take 12 and 13 to the locations below them where they go anyway but I can't see where pin 11 would go.

Repairable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
Use schematic/boardview to follow the traces.
You must cover the ground from second layer, if visible.
I use small kapton tape parts for such job; and 0.01-0.03mm wires to recover the pads.
